title: Grade 7
subject: Alternative Content Standards - English Language Arts (2017-)

document.title: ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR GRADE 7: ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTS

5843D742AAF849AAA314E8FC7D1CC008.description:
Select or create
audio recordings and
visual/tactile displays to
emphasize specific points in a
presentation.

4419FA5CD5FA4AAC9C0D3C37B2994FB1.description:
Identify quotes
providing relevant information
about a topic from multiple
print or digital sources.

67424086619948A5B868346BD146722C.description:
Conduct research to
answer a question based on
multiple sources of
information.

E567E75F75CB48C5A90D07DFDB69EB15.description:
Use technology,
including the Internet, to
produce writing to interact and
collaborate with others.

86E62E86666E462FB151A6D68BB1F993.description:
The student can
identify a word or phrase paired
with a picture that describes the
feelings of a person/character in a
text.

675F9E4EDA414B20A7760DB014200230.description:
The student can
identify words or a phrase that
describes the feelings of the
people/characters in a text.

98FDCBE48D7E4515A2656FF616CCD7C7.description:
The student can
identify/use words to describe the
feelings of people/characters in a
text.

82F31BB5FE204F14902CC057C1A69F92.description:
Write about
events or personal experiences:
Use words that describe feelings of
people or characters in the
narrative.

6D0A1EEF763C482FAA6AF7E8442C7CF4.description:
The student can
select a fact, detail, or other piece of
information that relates to a given
topic.

E283433B47AB4C62B48E704A09B59F81.description:
The student can
select facts, details, or other pieces
of information that relate to a given
topic.

1560B008FAEA458E8E50CD6AF4785520.description:
The student can
identify/list/organize facts, details,
or other pieces of information to
support a topic.

EC0B78A36C014329831946EFEE0F7C78.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details: Provide facts, details, or
other information related to the
topic.

DC332DAAD13A4E9B993F910864D9E357.description: Students can investigate topics and present information.

2A6A561B57004471A71DDAE238AB6BB7.description:
Use general academic
and domain-specific words and
phrases across contexts.

EA8E3CC1B7DA455DA123F19294DF9F0D.description:
The student can identify
the correct use of language to
communicate effectively with
familiar people (e.g., sharing
information, responding to
greetings, being polite, and making
simple requests, etc.).

63AED6BCC4A14876980D416DF652A896.description:
The student can use
language to communicate
effectively with a variety of
audiences and for different
purposes (e.g., asking questions,
sharing information, responding to
greetings, using polite expressions,
using appropriate body language).

7A26F1DA524044CA98CB3215C009C4CE.description:
The student can use
language to communicate
effectively with peers and adults
(e.g., asking and answering
questions, providing more
information when someone does
not understand the first time,
sharing information, making
requests, etc.).

EA1364B60BCB416BACD27233F8E89768.description:
Use language to
achieve desired outcomes when
communicating.

4E95BA6F85E9456494036241212F66C3.description:
Demonstrate
Standard English grammar and
usage when communicating:
Produce complete simple sentences
when writing or communicating.

AFF96F2415B0497C827FA1BB5398499F.description:
Communicate
precisely (i.e., provide complete
information) or efficiently (i.e.,
telegraphic communication) as
required by the context, task,
and communication partner.

4932F6E84C5A4BDCB3C67720C01318CC.description:
Present findings on a
topic including relevant
descriptions, facts, or details.

952F6F68D139461EA4F6A3E5D0237908.description:
The student can select
one or more details from
information presented orally or
through other media.

18BE55EC06C940AA8F19D50EC22169DE.description:
The student can
distinguish whether a piece of
information shared by a speaker is a
fact.

9951A39E0EFA4A0AA7C513A25E150237.description:
The student can
determine whether the information
provided by a speaker is based on
fact or opinion.

52737C37A7E444F098E83BEF9BE54A61.description:
Determine whether
the claims made by a speaker
are fact or opinion.

35645EED1F1A476A959F400EB0767E2E.description:
Identify details
related to the main idea of a
text presented orally or through
other media.

3B3ADC7AC42E4DAF903A31EC8F1EE290.description:
Engage in
collaborative discussions. A.
Come to discussions prepared to
share information. B. With guidance
and support from adults and peers,
follow simple, agreed-upon rules
for discussions and carry out
assigned roles. C. Remain on the
topic of the discussion when
answering questions or making
other contributions to a discussion.
D. Acknowledge new information
expressed by others in a discussion.

61D220375ECC4C99A53E7A16E14C0777.description: Students can communicate for a range of purposes and audiences.

DE321FD6E9B244199527D537296B3A2E.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions
of Standard English: Spell words
phonetically, drawing on
knowledge of letter-sound
relationships and/or common
spelling patterns.

C853E1120BF0455BAF2245B24AB53F39.description:
The student can
differentiate if a sentence is a
statement or a question.

9A0F9A1E13D940CB9047FC8EB9BFF053.description:
The student can
identify capital letters and/or basic
punctuation (periods and question
marks).

88243653081343C59A913C8AAA0FB8A2.description:
The student can
identify which word/words should
be capitalized in a sentence (first
words and proper nouns) and/or
choose the correct ending
punctuation (period, question mark,
or exclamation point).

7AA37FFD55D24F9689BB0348BCEAF5B6.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions
of Standard English: Use end
punctuation when writing a
sentence or question.

B599219814044DEE9DD41F4B9BBFAEB3.description:
Write routinely for a
variety of tasks, purposes, and
audiences.

78FEB5D5CC944BA8A5DA0D8068DCD084.description:
Use information from
literary and informational text to
support writing. A. Apply Essential
Elements of Grade 7 Reading
Standards to literature (e.g.,
“Recognize the difference between
fictional characters and nonfictional
characters.”). B. Apply Essential
Elements of Grade 7 Reading
Standards to informational texts (e.g.,
“Use relevant and sufficient evidence
for supporting the claims and
argument.”).

5EA3AD781768413C872EAA27AD78D22A.description:
With guidance and
support from adults and peers,
plan before writing and revise
own writing.

A97EF94C60794665A791150BCFA16AC9.description:
Produce writing that is
appropriate for the task, purpose,
or audience.

1A1663A640B14E41B5FF7B16155836E9.description:
Write about events
or personal experiences: Use
temporal words (e.g., first, then, next)
to signal order.

1952BB99FB09412DBE3770A624F9DC1A.description:
The student can
provide a detail (paired with a
picture) about a person/character,
while preparing to
write/communicate about an event
or personal experience.

9E8C2FECA77440E3BA32101ED95B5344.description:
The student can
provide details about one
person/character or one
action/happening that occurred
during an event or personal
experience, while preparing to
write/communicate about it.

89C355CE2DA44C99A2EA3D6FEB897FEF.description:
The student can
write/draw/dictate about an event
or personal experience, including at
least one person/character and one
action/happening.

1A734C76D97641E9B6AB8DC8B64430E7.description:
Write about events
or personal experiences: Write a
narrative about a real or imagined
experience, at least one character,
and two or more events.

EFB7CA900D854CEDB8D1B985099FD01C.description:
Write to share
information supported by details:
A. Introduce a topic and write to
convey ideas and information about it
including visual, tactual or multimedia
information as appropriate. D. Select
domain-specific vocabulary to use in
writing about the topic.

2FD75362E44041D6A8F4F44F660DABF1.description:
Write claims about
topics or texts. A. Introduce a topic
or text and write one claim about it.
B. Write one or more reasons to
support a claim about a topic or text.
C. Use temporal words (e.g., first,
next, also) to create cohesion.

5877576350DF4BD5BDC45F7DF8C6C389.description: Students can produce writing for a range of purposes and audiences.

04B7DF60FD234058B3BC6F33A48BB690.description:
The student can
identify a word with the opposite
meaning as a target word that
appears in a short text.

9334CE87ED224101941715C1A107E380.description:
The student can
identify a word with the opposite
meaning as a target word that
appears in text.

DF36B8DF262B4E3C83900C68B1B5B231.description:
The student can
demonstrate understanding of
words with the same or different
meanings (synonyms and
antonyms).

45D16DF53E354C7A8702F5CA4D11D424.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use:
Demonstrate understanding of
synonyms and antonyms.

1537E7FB4550441584466AB427D9EC71.description:
The student can
identify the meaning of a word or
phrase used in a given context
given choices of words paired with
pictures/objects.

CDCCF6BC4ED34340B04844D9A6EA9C76.description:
The student can
identify the correct word (from
commonly confused words) to use
in a given context.

B13BABAD87104717A20C4D8F47871C46.description:
The student can
identify the meaning of literal or
non-literal/figurative words or
phrases when presented in the
context of narrative or informational
text.

CB552879D4CF47FBAB53A3B070B514EC.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use: Identify
the literal and nonliteral meanings
of words in context.

25AD45EB13FC4899B62BDD8D1EC64108.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Seek clarification and meaning
support when unfamiliar words are
encountered while reading or
communicating.

2A9A819A6B03458FBA39C422CF79E641.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Use frequently occurring root
words (e.g., like) and the words that
result when affixes are added (e.g.,
liked, disliked, liking).

FF33530339184482999434FC8DDB635D.description:
The student can use
cues to recognize the meaning of
familiar words when paired with
pictures.

C8FB9B9EA10C4391AD5C29709AD27A53.description:
The student can use
context clues to determine the
meaning of familiar words paired
with pictures and/or objects.

CFAFB17081B74CBAAE83E14EF87EFED7.description:
The student can use
context as a clue to guide selection
of a word or words that best
completes a sentence.

E1339975BF544728BD6CC25782A758B6.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Use context to determine which
word is missing from a text.

192BCBE7396E4F88AFD2DC2786FFC18C.description:
Demonstrate
understanding while actively
reading or listening to literary
nonfiction.

C09A720B5A5B43A1AB9769BB44C2F6F3.description:
Compare and
contrast how different texts on
the same topic present the
details.

9FDB913EF14D40F981AC0A606146BFDB.description:
Determine how a
claim or reason fits into the
overall structure of an
informational text.

9C8DCF2EC64740C8867D613FDC611554.description:
Compare a text to an
audio, video or multimedia
version of the same text.

4094C19ACA8F4799BCB76876524DC22E.description:
The student can identify
the purpose of an
informational/functional text (e.g.,
to tell about events, give directions,
provide information) using
words/phrases paired with pictures.

006C733D517F4FDAA2331D6CA8A81312.description:
The student can
select words/phrases that show
how the author feels about the
topic of an informational text or
identify why the author most likely
wrote it.

0BC5E910DC254DBBB8BAC7E23F70164E.description:
The student can
identify the author’s point of view or
his/her purpose for writing an
informational text.

E5D7F0315EFD41B4ABFDC9BE5E290599.description:
Determine an
author’s purpose or point of
view.

81C7D7E5CCAF4D07B7B248A3462F0895.description:
The student can answer
simple questions regarding a variety
of basic informational/functional
text (e.g., awareness of daily
schedule, calendars, dictionary,
phone directories, etc.).

87F649C8DF074E038D3B7774F9699E6C.description:
The student can
identify a variety of
informational/functional texts
and/or text patterns (e.g.,
problem/solution, sequence/order,
same/different, cause/effect,
descriptive).

D7B9A914B08149AC9A72E84CDB06751E.description:
The student can
identify how an informational text
has been organized by the author
(e.g., problem/solution,
sequence/order, compare/contrast,
cause/effect, descriptive) and/or
indicate how a fact, step, or event
fits into the text structure.

3645C28DFD8D41B2B6CF1B402C723071.description:
Determine how a
fact, step, or event fits into the
overall structure of the text.

3A916218B84C49EC836EB62FA2F94980.description:
Determine how
words or phrases are used to
persuade or inform a text.

3FE4D42A219246CEAAB48B0A7A64F138.description:
The student can identify
what is the same between two
individuals within a short
informational text.

91F86A10020243C091E46D02DFC41252.description:
The student can
identify which informational text
element is associated with a given
text element. (Example: Under
which heading does given
information go in a chart?).

2647912C9BF04BA3A807D4B81B52B6C8.description:
The student can
indicate how two individuals,
events, or ideas in an informational
text are related.

2DD106BC131B46BEA8E60B923A909E9A.description:
Determine how two
individuals, events or ideas in a
text are related.

B78A56DEC42040929D2AD68C5430410E.description:
The student can identify
the main idea of a short
informational text.

F0BEEB3EC6DB44F1ACE2052DA1F5DB27.description:
The student can
identify one detail that relates to
the main idea of a short
informational text (when the main
idea is provided).

63040A3A271F448B99A3E4EDCCE82078.description:
The student can
identify one or more central ideas in
an informational text.

41910086E756407C948F70DEEB1B6FBA.description:
Determine two or
more central ideas in a text.

72690A7F1488436283263DD93A1D0C1B.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
who, what, where, or when
questions about short informational
text.

DE49A2B0C16B410D9787DD700D216E45.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
questions and make predictions
about a short informational text.

088857BE62304047A86C56A69742BC76.description:
The student can use
details and clues from informational
text to answer questions and make
inferences.

6C1DEC12FFB14F23A827DF3FD1279FE2.description:
Analyze text to
identify where information is
explicitly stated and where
inferences must be drawn.

01255F8C87C44383BEE3100A42FA9F17.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of text while
actively reading or listening to
stories, dramas, or poetry.

EE90BED8AA8A4F9B9D8F7F82017A5333.description:
Compare a fictional
time, place, or character in one
text with the same time, place,
or character portrayed in a
historical account.

9FFA87D4B6CD485C8D4A9BEF0EB31C1D.description:
Compare a text
version of a story, drama, or
poem with an audio, video, or
live version of the same text.

0982F12BADFC4904B4C1D902E434345A.description:
Compare the points
of view of two or more
characters or narrators in a
text.

520AD6241D6E43F4B10708502A524D9C.description:
Compare the
structure of two or more texts
(e.g., stories, poems, or
dramas).

04A23999BB21499D90C09B210DD9CD00.description:
Determine the
meaning of simple idioms and
figures of speech as they are
used in a text.

B03B77ECBADA41F69B19446FD7139FFF.description:
The student can
identify what is the same between
two characters when given a visual
model to match.

C7AB7FB7E67A400792B8869FBFF0999E.description:
The student can
identify which story element is
associated with a given story
element.

2C561664534E4EA08225B87D4C3DCB0D.description:
The student can
indicate how two or more story
elements are related.

32C04011B875409C98549D054892D516.description:
Determine how two
or more story elements are
related.

A240790961AF45249B1712921D404213.description:
The student can
identify the theme or main idea of a
short narrative text.

CC86B50A742C466799889AAFF33208DE.description:
The student can
identify one detail that relates to
the theme or main idea of a short
narrative text (when the theme or
main idea is provided).

A46EEFB8E8DD43FFAE20744F96017B13.description:
The student can
identify one or more details in a
narrative text that are related to the
text’s theme or main idea.

086B16A3DF5544A8AE873E94AC026A28.description:
Identify events in a
text that are related to the
theme or central idea.

81B7A09537EF44048220AAA1F698F9C9.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
who, what, where, or when
questions about short narrative
text.

AF364553225141818A1EF80F45A6F3AF.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
questions and make predictions
about short narrative text.

F037F968C0AF4666A17B70899C9D852F.description:
The student can
answer questions about narrative
text using explicit details and clues
to make inferences.

7DB6111632124E47BFF19774116F4579.description:
Analyze text to
identify where information is
explicitly stated and where
inferences must be drawn.

7D1659FBA26F48DA878B75E535C66885.description: Students can comprehend text in increasingly complex ways.
